Evaluation_Questions: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken
What is your overall assessment of this course
What is your overall rating of the primary instructor
The primary instructor's provided students with helpful and timely feedback
The instructor established a positive learning environment
The instructor raised questions or problems that encouraged me to think critically
Comments_Questions: Indicate the total number of hours per week (outside the classroom) you spent on this course
Looking back on this course, what is your overall assessment of the course:  What are its strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might it be improved
Please evaluate the instructor of this course. What are the instructor's strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might his or her teaching be improved?
How would you summarize this course for a fellow student?  Would you recommend it to another student?  Why or why not
Comments_List: 5 Hours
Somewhere between 4 and 6. Sometimes more.
3 on normal week. 5-7 for exams
2 hours/week
3 hours/week
About four hours per week.
5 hours
8.  For someone like me who has no economics background, going to the TA was a must, and also to the extent available so was listening to the lectures on video.
~3 hours
5-10 hours
AP- on a week with no tests, 2.5 hours reading, note making and problem sets
5-8 hours
Approx 4hours in most weeks, longer in weeks prior to exams or quizzes
2-3 hours
Important information to learn!

Interesting and useful material.
Help you think critically.
It is a bit fast as expected. It's only once a week and it always feels rushed. I do appreciate that it is now recorded, and I like having section time to go over the material again.
Good pacing, but some things were a bit unclear.
I feel that I learned a lot from this course. However, I felt that some of the quiz and test questions did not do a good job of adequately measuring understanding of the material covered.

The course is excellent. Useful, important etc. 
Professor Friedman's lectures are superb-- definitely among the best.
The biggest weakness of the course is the lack of feedback on the homework. For the math, the calculations do explain. But for the other questions where viewpoint" was either right or wrong, even though the TA's were AWESOME. After asking the TA's a few times, I sort of gave up.  I got the "that's a really good point" or "that makes sense". 
That said. Take this course. PERIOD.
This is an excellent course! The structure of the course is logical and thoughtful in its design. We covered a lot of material but it didn't feel too rushed.

This class is truly a masterpiece. I love how it is designed so that I can really learn new concepts. Book is easy, class a bit harder, homework problems and exams very challenging. I would recommend it to everyone, and I will honestly miss this course next semester. 

What could be improved: I went back and relistened to The insurance stuff. Still confusing, the practice problems were way clearer. I have to say I do wish homework were a part of our grade, perhaps graded pass/fail like in epi. Thats bc I find this homework to be crucial to understanding but I find it hard to prioritize it against graded assignments for other courses. If graded pass fail, dont need to worry about academic integrity issue.

- Strengths: broad content that touched on important topics, good sections and TAs, clear structure
- Improvements: make links between theoretical concepts and real life policy issues more explicit
If you've never taken econ before, it's not a very challenging class that teaches you how to think about U.S. healthcare from an economic perspective.

Strengths: great TA selection The TAs for this course were the best of any I took this semester; practice problems were worth doing and helped with course contentprioritization structure is MUCH appreciated.  Content is well-organized and in a sensical order.
Weaknesses: lectures were sometimes a little hard to follow; I often learned more in section
Very well structured and organized. Great foundation of microeconomics topics.
Amazing course

AP- 
Strengths: Well-structured, smoothly-run introduction to microeconomics with a HP slant; especially enjoyed the arc of the course in building upon fundamental econ principles to incorporate more complex health-related issues. As someone without prior microecon experience, Prof Friedman was excellent in explaining concepts. The video recordings during the second half of the course really clarified concepts that were difficult to catch on-the-fly during class.
Fair quiz/test assessments, usually each with one "do you really understand this stuff" question.
The perfect amount of practice questions available during the second half of the course. Wish there were a few more earlier on.

Weaknesses: lectures are quite fast-paced, requiring several repeat listens.
It was a good course. The speed of the class is a bit quick, but we had a lot of material to go over. I definitely learned the most from this class.

This course was absolutely amazing and it taught me so much that can be applied to a real world context. I really appreciate how Dr. Friedman used many healthcare examples because it helped put things into a relevant context. I think the strength of the class is how applicable it is to the creation of policies in conjunction to understanding market explanations in the media. This class has definitely shaped how I will think about my own life along with thinking about why policymakers think the way they do, especially those who claim to fiscal conservatives. The only weakness I can see is that it is only once a week: I think if it were twice a week, that'd be nice just so we could go a bit slower but if there could be recordings of the lectures from the beginning, that would also be incredibly helpful.
Absolutely loved it. Although it was a hard course, I found myself to be engaged and can apply these concepts to my future career.
This was top 2 favorite classes this semester. very well taught and engaging
Good introduction to microecon. Assignments and section were helpful for a topic I have no knowledge in.

Strengths: Expected a lot from students, fast-paced, covered a lot of relevant material, group consulting class, TA's were great about answering questions
Weaknesses: Sometimes the concepts were confusing and despite taking the course, I still find myself not 100% sure on some of them
Improvement: We had a quiz right after the midterm. The quiz should either be taken a few weeks later or there should be another quiz. This way, students will know the material better.

This course was incredibly useful and helpful. Of all the courses I took the semester this was the best in terms of building new skills. The instructor and the TFs were very helpful and knowledgeable, respectful, and engaging. I do not have any suggestions to improve this course.
I really appreciated this course and thought it was very good. It was a very good level and speed for someone who had never studied economics before.

This is a great course to get a strong foundation in the applications of microeconomics to healthcare. The content is well laid out, and the class moves at a good pace. Professor Friedman's lectures are engaging, and the TAs are really nice and responsive to questions. I also appreciated how accommodating and helpful Professor Friedman was when unexpected events occurred that affected our academics.
Great Class
Video lectures helped. Powerpoint files would help.

I really liked the course, but I always felt like I was behind since I did not understand the subject matter well enough.  This should be treated as an overview of microeconomics, it puts too much pressure to try to learn every aspect of every lecture.

This course covers a lot of material but is not overwhelming in terms of weekly deliverables which I consider a strength when matched up with other classes that have more "busy" work. The homework assignments are for the student's benefit to complete and are not collected nor graded. Attending section is the chance to go over lecture material homework assignments, and ask questions.
This is a good course, however it can be hard to keep up with all the new concepts.
It's a very fast paced and taxing class but incredibly rewarding. A lot of foundational information that was taught are concepts that I have started applying to my own life.
very fast and would be helpful to have class twice a week rather than once a week

This course is so valuable. It changes the way you view public health issues and provides a solid foundation for economic evaluation. The only suggestion I have would be splitting it into a twice a week class.
Phenomenal professor. Engaging content. Very accelerated though, so didnt get to dig into each concept deeply.
My favorite class of the semester! The subject matter was difficult, but it was presented in a very engaging way and I enjoyed the challenge.
Graded homework would have been beneficial. Sections were very good and helpful.

AP Strengths: Covers a lot of material
Weaknesses: The pace of the course seems too fast at the start and too slow at the end. I spent a lot of time on the maths practice and derivatives when the actual knowledge level required was to a much more basic standard so I felt I wasted my time on that.

Greatest strength was the pairing of lectures and section. I wish I had had the time to go to more sections. The lectures, especially once they started being recorded, were GREAT. I would go to class, then watch the lectures again (mainly because the pace of class lectures is INCREDIBLY FAST! too fast almost...) 
The book was good but not amazing/not as good as lecture and sections. Overall, the biggest weakness of this class is the pace, but the professor and TFs are cognizant and do their best to be available and helpful. I would urge that the classes are recorded from the start, not mid-semester.
The course was well organized. Notes were clear and problem sets were very useful to help consolidate and review learning material.

Very important introduction to concepts of microeconomics, however I wish the complicated concepts were presented in a more accessible manner. Many times coming to class and reading lecture notes would not help with my understanding of the concepts. I had to look at YouTube videos in order to understand concepts.

I love how this microecon course is tailtor to health policy and management. It really allowed me to think about healthcare problems in a different way, and I can already tell the materials from this course will be built upon in future courses.

Perhaps have a better understanding of where everyone is in the class and not make any assumptions on the various levels of expertise that exist. Provide recordings of the class because it is hard to capture everything she says in one sitting.

Incredible.
Great in explaining, and extremely clear.
Class is really engaging.

She is SO passionate. I can't think of anyone else I'd want to learn microecon of PH here. She inspires me (even though microecon is probably the most challenging course for me right now) to continue at it even after this course is finished, to integrate microecon into my career.
I appreciated Dr. Friedman's willingness to meet outside of class and felt that she was very helpful and engaged in the learning of students enrolled in the course.
Dr. Friedman was a very engaging professor. She really went above and beyond to explain important concepts.
She is simply superb.

Professor Friedman is great. She clearly cares a lot about her students and economics, and so makes the classroom engaging and interesting. She consistently tied in-class concepts back to public health so that we understood how the content we were learning actually applied to the real world.

I think professor friedman is the best instructor we have at YSPH. I was shocked she hasnt won that award already . Every SINGLE thing she does and says to the class is well thought out and she tries really hard to balance the applied math part of things with fun and interesting activities relating to health. I have said no less than 100 times since this semester started,  wow, Abby should design all of the core classes.  I know it cant be challenging to make a dry and difficult subject worth learning and interesting (Cough biostatistics cough), but the effort she put into this class makes it so. 

Only weakness I can think of is that I do kinda wish there was a set office hour. Sometimes I would love to drop by and get to know my professor, but making an appointment seems to formal for that. I feel like I have to do some kind of work (like read your paper) or have an academic problem to make an appointment, but if you had set office hours, I probably would drop by.

- Strengths: engaging and humorous lectures, gives many simple examples to explain concepts, provides students with incentives to learn
- Weaknesses: speaks too fast in lectures

Very knowledgeable and clear about what she is explaining. I think the course can be further improved if the practice problems after each lecture were refined. The questions from the textbook were frankly too conceptual and didn't help practice what we learned in class. I also noticed that some of the answer keys contained errors, so it would be great if they could be fixed.

This course was highly theoretical, which makes sense for an intro course, but when we did go into examples, I felt like the liberal view was very well represented, and the conservative argument was diminished.  Which ultimately does us all a disservice.

I really appreciate how much Dr. Friedman cares about us and our missions in life.
Brilliant. Very thoughtful and purposeful with her content and discussion. Sometimes concepts went over my head so I had to go back, but overall - great!
Great instructor

AP-
Incredibly organized and thoughtful instructor. Truly cares about student engagement and understanding. Appreciated her efforts to steer the large class towards collective understanding, being mindful of timing and steering away from superfluous/unrelated student questions during class. Commend her efforts during the second half of the course (after mid-term evals) to incorporate student feedback about recording coursework and ensuring that students had a good understanding of concepts throughout the fast-paced lectures. Initially spoke a little too quickly for my in-class understanding, but this was appropriately adjusted during the second half of the course.
She was very accommodating to students. I appreciated when she started recording the class.

Dr. Friedman is one of my favorite professors of all time! The only economics class I've ever taken was in high school so I wasn't sure if I would do well in this class but Dr. Friedman is very clear when she speaks and whenever people are confused, she explains it in multiple ways to help clear up any concepts. I also really like how she structured the class because I think making the practice problems not for points made me feel more engaged because I was more interested in learning the material rather than just figuring out what the right answer was. I don't think she has any weaknesses! The class went a bit quick but that was understandable due to the amount of material and few hours of lecture time.
She is an amazing and engaging lecturer. Knows how to explain complex concepts in easy relatable terms.

Professor Friedman was absolutely amazing. She is brilliant and is always willing to help her students out to better understand difficult concepts. Lectures were always engaging and class activities were fun to be a part of.

The professor was amazing. Created a positive learning environment by providing tangible real life example and making the evaluation of this course fair. She was also great at taking feedback from students and applying it right there and then. Just wish she would slow down a little during lectures but otherwise it was great.
very good, lectures are engaging and in combination with TA review sessions I learned a lot.

Strengths: Very knowledgeable, could answer any question thrown her way
Weaknesses: At times a little harsh or direct
Improvements: Possibly could work on sounding a little more positive

I do not have any improvement suggestions for the instructor. She was genuinely kind, respectful, and supportive of all students and fostered a great learning environment. We covered vey complex topics in an engaging and manageable way. This class and the instructor make me want to take more health econ courses at Yale.
She is incredibly competent, helpful, and approachable. She knows her stuff. I am glad I took the class with her.
Abby is an incredible professor. I learned so much during her class, and she was receptive to feedback and really cared about her students.

Professor Friedman is great!!! If she is offering this course again, I definitely recommend taking it. She is so smart and engaging! She makes the material accessible and explains the complex concepts well. She is also very good about answering our questions well! Overall, an amazing professor! I have no suggestions for improvement
Great Teacher
See above
Professor Friedman was great.  A little short sometimes with answering question, but I think its because we were trying to crunch so much into a small amount of time.

Professor Friedman is an amazing professor for this course. She is extremely thorough in lecture and is able to teach loads of material in limited time. She makes lecture fun and engaging for students.

Great professor and lecturer. Further, you can tell that she cares about her students and their understanding of the concepts. She can go a little fast at times, so I think it is very important that we keep up the trend of recording the lectures.

Professor Friedman is an amazing instructor. She encourages you to study as hard as you can but understands the difficulties of being a graduate student. She always has her student's well beings in mind above all else.
great instructor
Professor Friedman is amazing. She is incredibly thoughtful about the way she presents information, is really engaging, and makes the material easy to understand.
Absolutely phenomenal. Very knowledgeable and insightful. Her wrap up of the course at the end of the semester was insightful, thought-provoking, and outstandingly well-done.
Talks too fast sometimes. Otherwise, amazing Prof who cares about her students and clearly dedicates a lot of time into preparing engaging lessons.

Professor Friedman is one of those professors who has mastered her subject so well that she's able to make it accessible and engaging to any audience. She did a great job of presenting the material in a greater public health/ societal context. Definitely happy I took this course!
Semester started a little rough, but got better. Became more receptive to questions.

AP: Strengths: Prof Friedman knows the topic well. 
Weaknesses: At times she seemed frustrated when people asked questions or appeared not to understand the material. 
Areas for improvement: It was not always easy for me to identify the critical learning points from each lecture ie what was emphasised in class wasn't always what was in the tests. The problems in the problem sets did not always emphasise the critical learning points either. It would be helpful to have the answers to in the in-class problems included on the lecture slide-decks in order to make studying easier.
Professor Friedman's lectures were really helpful. She used examples that not only made sense but were interesting and pertinent to public health (which cannot be said about other classes).

The instructor taught in a clear and comprehensive manner. I did feel that some of the lectures moved quite quickly so could be challenging to follow however 'section hours' really helped to review material and allowed us to ask questions that we may not have thought to ask during class.

Excellent commitment to teaching and to us as students. I wish the material was presented in a more accessible manner. Given that this was an introductory course, more could have been done to simplify the language and methods used to explain the very complicated concepts that we were learning about.
Professor Friedman is excellent. She presents the information in a clear and engaging way. She writes tough quizzes and exams but is a fair grader.
She is great!
She was unfriendly, difficult and lacked the teacher-student relationship
It is a course that is necessary for anyone interested in understanding how the health care market works!

Really good course. 
Basic microeconomics, really useful material.
Really good professor.
Challenging, but very useful. Highly recommend.
I would recommend this course to a fellow student.

Very important.
Very well taught.
Take the course.
This is a fantastic course and a great intro to economics. Take this class!!
Good introduction to basic microeconomics concepts in relation to healthcare, would recommend to other students
If you've never taken econ before, it's not a very challenging class that teaches you how to think about U.S. healthcare from an economic perspective.

Im not that interested economics, and often found the course tedious.  That being said, I feel like I have a very good understanding of microeconomics after this course, so it worked.  Recommend if you want a detailed, solid foundation of the basics.  Not my favorite class, but overall a success of a course.
Provides excellent foundation - worthwhile course!
Yes, but be aware that the exams are challenging

AP- fast-paced (for those without microecon experience) but very informative in teaching how to "think" econ as opposed to just memorize formulas. Excellent efforts by Prof Friedman to incorporate health-related examples. Can't stress how helpful the video recordings were in re-listening to Prof Friedman's explanations.
It was a great class. I would highly recommend taking it even if you're not a health policy concentrator.

ABSOLUTELY. This course was one of my favorite courses that I've taken in my life. I think that it prepares people really well in terms of understanding what policymakers say, which makes this class extremely valuable for those who want to pursue government work. I would recommend it to people who have also taken a microeconomics course before because Dr. Friedman discussed these concepts in a health context and she also delves deeply into the Arrow 1963 paper that, I assume, most other classes wouldn't but is incredibly valuable for understanding the healthcare market.
I would encourage every MPH student to take this course. Helped me to develop a new understanding of the health system.

I would say that this course is challenging but it is one of the courses I have learned the most in. Information covered was highly relevant and I truly feel smarter and more capable of engaging in discussions about current events than I was prior to taking this course.
Yes, although it was challenging, it is such an important course and the topics are truly relevant to my career trajectory.
Very interesting, would highly recommend, I learned a lot and it is relevant to other courses/things I am interested in in the world

I would definitely recommend this course. Despite being challenging, it was very useful to understanding how the U.S. market system functions at a household and firm level. It has made me think differently and not just in a public health way.

I would 100% recommend this course to another student. This course provides you with the skills to understand and evaluate economic arguments as they relate to health policy on a broad range of issues. This definitely one of the most useful and interesting classes I have taken in my undergraduate and graduate education.
I would summarize this course as an approachable introduction to microeconomics tailored to public health. I would definitely recommend it.

This is a great course for someone with little to no experience in economics and who is interested in building a strong foundation in the application of economics to healthcare. I would definitely recommend this to another student!
Great. Will recommend
This is a very fast paced, busy course with a lot of material, but as long as you pay attention during lecture, do the homework assignments, and attend section, you'll do great!
Good course. It really pushes you to better understand the concepts. I would strongly recommend reading the book, otherwise it is easy to get lost.
Highly recommend! Great class with wonderful concepts.
good course, very interesting but need some econ background
Learn the basics of microeconomics, what assumptions don't apply to the US Health Care System. Definitely recommend!
Very accelerated. Somewhat difficult at times due to the amount necessary to synthesize, given the relatively small face time (once per week).
Would recommend - good intro to Microecon. Great Professor.
I have and would continue to recommend this course to other students!
It was ok, economics is a tough subject, but I've used some of the concepts already.

AP: A good introduction to microeconomics. I am not really sure how I will use this in my particular career but I did find it interesting from a general knowledge perspective and it certainly was a challenge. I  personally didn't enjoy the class environment. I would recommend getting a copy of the textbook, I found that really helpful.

I walked in knowing practically nothing about microeconomics and walked out knowing SO MUCH more and feeling proud of what I know (despite maybe not fully understanding everything). This class was awesome and even though Econ has always been a little scary, Professor Friedman made it really interesting and manageable. It's a very fast paced course but incredibly worthwhile to put in the effort.
I would definitely recommend it to a fellow student. As someone who has no background in economics, I found it to be a very good introduction to the subject while still being thorough.

Interesting and necessary but not complicated topics not easy to digest without significant time spent outside of class and utilizing external materials. I resorted to YouTube because lectures were not very helpful in simplifying complicated concepts.
Absolutely instrumental course to understand challenges in healthcare. Highly recommend!
